DataElement.preferredName: Distance From Ventricle to Tumor Millimeter Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric value representing the neuro anatomy distance from any ventricle in the brain to a specified primary tumor measured in millimeters (mm).

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The four connected cavities (hollow spaces) centrally located within the brain that connect posteriorly with the central canal of the spinal cord._Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._The space separating two objects or points.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The four connected cavities (hollow spaces) centrally located within the brain that connect posteriorly with the central canal of the spinal cord.:Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: The four connected cavities (hollow spaces) centrally located within the brain that connect posteriorly with the central canal of the spinal cord.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: The space between two objects or points.

Concepts.definition: The space separating two objects or points.
